sub_title: Assistant Professor at Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management, Erasmus University Rotterdam
summary:
I am trained as a sociologist at the University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands. In 2016, at that same university, I successfully defended my PhD thesis on the interactions between the governance of uncertain health risks and citizens’ experiences of these risks. During these studies I was intrigued by sociological work on risk, medical sociology and health policy, and qualitative methods such as ethnography and discourse analysis. At the end of my PhD I worked as a postdoc at the Athena Institute at VU Amsterdam where my interest in patient and client participation was strengthened, in particular by engaging in research with patients themselves.

My start in 2016 as assistant professor at the Healthcare Governance department of the Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management at the Erasmus University Rotterdam allowed me to further develop my interests in the sociology of risk and uncertainty, and in patient and client participation research. Next to teaching in our Healthcare Management master program, I engaged in different research projects with the Dutch Health and Youth Care Inspectorate (IGJ) on patient and client participation in healthcare supervision. I very much value this close connection between academic research and practice, and I examined amongst other how and in what way patients’ experiential knowledge works in regulatory practices in elderly care and mental healthcare. How concepts of risk play out in regulatory practice is the question one of the PhD students (Mireille Kroekenstoel) I supervise is currently working on. In 2018 I became coordinator of our Academic Collaboration with the Dutch National Healthcare Institute (ZIN). In this collaboration I am able to develop similar questions on risk, uncertainty and participation but now in relation to issues of healthcare quality and valuation through supervising PhD students (Jolien van de Sande, Renee Michels). 

Currently my own empirical research focuses on healthcare during the COVID-19 pandemic. Right at the start of the pandemic we were able to acquire funding from NWO to closely follow the healthcare governance of the pandemic in the Netherlands by engaging in (digital) organizational ethnography. Before the summer of 2020 we did fieldwork on the level of one university hospital, afterwards we moved this research, through acquiring funds from ZonMW, to focus on the regional and national level in the Netherlands. Our aim is to keep following, and reflecting with key-actors in, the healthcare governance of the pandemic until October 2022.

Last update: April 2021

company.name: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management

profile_positions.company: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
profile_positions.description: At the section Healthcare Governance of ESHPM (former iBMG), I teach and work on research projects concerning the sociological analysis of the work that goes into governing healthcare. I focus in particular on questions about citizen and patient participation with the governance of risk and uncertainties in healthcare, doing so for instance with the Dutch Health and Youth Care Inspectorate (IGJ) and the Dutch National Healthcare Institute (ZIN).
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor Healthcare Governance

profile_positions.description: I teach at the Athena Institute at VU Amsterdam within the section Science Communication. I am involved in different research projects that focus on risk communication and patient participation in research and health care.
profile_positions.title: Postdoc & Lecturer Science Communication

company.name: Amsterdam Institute for Social Science Research (AISSR) / University of Amsterdam

profile_positions.description: A research entitled ‘Should I be Worried?’: Citizens experiences and the risk politics of cell site deployment. In the context of the five year project ‘Politics and Risk Communication’ at the Sociology Department of the University of Amsterdam, I investigate the interaction between citizens’ experiences of environmental health risks and the governance of a technology. My dissertation is available at www.riskpolitics.nl/dissertation.
profile_positions.title: PhD Student Sociology

profile_positions.description: Lecturing and coordinating studygroups on Sociology (Academic Skills and a broad introduction to Sociology).
profile_positions.title: Junior Lecturer Sociology

profile_positions.description: Lecturing and coordinating studygroups on Sociology (Introduction course).
profile_positions.title: Student Assistant

profile_positions.description: Visit to the Center for the Study of Democracy, a.o. to research cell site policy and citizen participation in the Southern California area.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Research Fellow

profile_positions.description: A research on end-of-life decision making regarding children administered to Intensive Care. Qualitative data analysis.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: Research into desegregation possibilities within primary schools in Amsterdam, with the focus on opinions of parents.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: Research into (client-) participation and governance in (elderly) care, welfare and housing in the Netherlands. Focused on the elderly care.
profile_positions.title: Internship/Research Assistant
